Geographical variation in thermal tolerance within Southern Ocean marine ectotherms. 
 
Simon A. Morley a,*, Timo Hirse b, Hans-Otto Pörtner b, Lloyd S. Peck a

Short title: geographic thermal tolerance 
 
Abstract 
Latitudinal comparisons of the Southern Ocean limpet, Nacella  concinna, and clam, Laternula 
elliptica, acclimated to 0.0°C, were used to assess differences in thermal response to two 
regimes, 0.0, 5.1 to 10.0°C and 2.5, 7.5 to 12.5°C, raised at 5.0°C per week. At each temperature, 
tissue energy status was measured through a combination of O2 consumption, intracellular pH, 
cCO2, citrate synthase (CS) activity, organic acids (succinate, acetate, propionate), andelylates 
(ATP, ADP, AMP, ITP, PLA (phospho-L-arginine)) and heart rate. L. elliptica from Signy 
(60ºS) and Rothera (67ºS) had the same lethal limits (7.5-10.0ºC), but small yet consistent 
indicators (O2, CS activity, PLA, ATP, organic acids and cCO2) suggest that Rothera L. elliptica 
had lower critical and pejus (=getting worse) limits than Signy L. elliptica. N. concinna, which 
experiences a wider thermal regime, had higher lethal limits (10.0-12.5ºC). However, at their 
Northern geographic limit N. concinna living in a warmer environment (South Georgia, 54ºS), 
had a lower critical limit (5.1-10.0ºC; O2, PLA and organic acids) than Rothera and Signy N. 
concinna (10.0-12.5ºC). This lower limit indicates that South Georgia N. concinna have different 
biochemical responses to temperatures close to their thermal limit, which may make them more 
vulnerable to future warming trends.

1. Introduction 
Applying the principles of symmorphosis (Weibel, 2000) to the oxygen supply cascade 
provides a conceptual framework to explain how temperature affects oxygen availability to 
tissues, and hence tissue energy status. This has developed towards a unifying principle that the 
physiological thermal limits of aquatic ectotherms are defined by oxygen availability, the 
balance between supply and demand (Pörtner, 2002; Pörtner, 2006; Peck et al., 2007). Within 
their optimal range ectotherms are expected to have the physiological flexibility to cope with 
normally experienced seasonal variation and tissue energy status should be maximal. However, 
in the face of extreme conditions, or towards range limits, aerobic scope is reduced, as more of 
the available energy is required to cope with routine metabolic processes and oxygen supply 
mechanisms become sub-optimal. There is growing evidence that the effects of thermal stress act 
hierarchically, from high to low complexity, i.e. whole body processes are affected before 
biochemical reactions and cells (Pörtner, 2002; Pörtner and Knust, 2007; Pörtner et al., 2007). 
Improving our understanding of how functionality is lost and energy is partitioned between 
processes will improve our understanding of the likely impact of climate change on species 
distributions and resulting ecosystem shifts. 
Thermal sensitivity can be assessed at a number of levels from whole animal activity 
through to tissue energy status and finally mortality. Characterising changes in tissue 
biochemistry has been developed as a test for critical thermal limits in aquatic ectotherms which 
indicate the transition to anaerobic metabolism (cf Pörtner, 2002). Within the window bounded 
by critical temperatures, an even narrower window is bordered by pejus limits (pejus: getting 
worse) which indicate when temperatures move beyond the optimal range and functionality starts 
to be lost, which is paralleled by a shortfall in oxygen supply and demand until critical limits are 
reached and anaerobic metabolic pathways are recruited. Species tested this way include the 
boreal freshwater gadoid, Lota lota (Hardewig et al., 2004), the worms, Sipunculus nudus 
(Zielinski and Pörtner, 1996), several populations of Arenicola marina (Sommer et al., 1997), 
and several Antarctic species (e.g. Limopsis marionensis; Pörtner et al., 1999) including both L. 
elliptica (Peck et al., 2002) and N. concinna (Pörtner et al., 1999). Biochemical parameters were

selected that measure the integrity of cellular systems and identify the temperature at which there 
is a departure from homeostasis (pHi and cCO2), with the main focus on those that measure the 
aerobic status of the animal, circulation (heart rate), aerobic metabolism (O2 consumption and 
citrate synthase activity), tissue energy status (balance of adenylates) and recruitment of 
anaerobic pathways (build up of organic acids). We aim to utilise these techniques to compare 
pejus limits, critical and lethal limits of N. concinna and L. elliptica from different locations 
within the Antarctic. These measures will be used to look for adaptive differences between 
locations that relate to experienced thermal environment. 
We exploit access to a unique latitudinal gradient within the Southern Ocean, Rothera 
(67°S), Signy (60°S) and South Georgia, (54°S) which enable us to separate latitude and 
temperature (Barnes et al. 2006). Our highest latitude site at Rothera Point, Adelaide Island, has 
an annual seawater temperature ranging from –2°C in winter to +1°C in the height of summer (at 
15m depth; Barnes et al., 2006). Signy Island, within the South Orkney Islands (60°C) is on the 
edge of the Weddell Sea gyre and despite its more northerly location has the same annual 
seawater temperature range to that of Rothera (Clarke and Leakey, 1996). However the sub-
Antarctic Island of South Georgia (54°S), although still within the Southern Ocean (south of the 
Antarctic circum-polar current) and therefore the biological Antarctic (Barnes et al., 2005), has 
almost twice the annual range due to a higher summer maximum (–1 to +4°C at 10-20m; Barnes 
et al., 2006). In response to the constant cold at Rothera benthic marine ectotherms are generally 
stenothermal, they have a limited temperature range, upper lethal limits typically occurring 
between 5 and 10ºC (Peck, 2005) but for some species are considerably lower than these, e.g. the 
brittle star Ophionotus victoriae which cannot survive even 1 month at 2°C (Peck et al, in press). 
Furthermore, limits for critical activities are often considerably lower than the lethal limits (2 to 
4ºC; Peck et al., 2004). The +4°C maximum summer seawater temperature at South Georgia 
therefore has the potential to impact these species, unless they have adaptive capacity to cope 
with this thermal range. It is interesting to note that the range of O. victoriae does not stretch as 
far as South Georgia.  
Symmorphosis (Weibel, 2000) and the climate variability hypothesis (Stevens, 1989) 
both predict that species, which experience a wider range of temperature, will have greater 
thermal flexibility. From this, sub-littoral species living at South Georgia should be able to cope 
with higher temperatures than the same species from Rothera. Habitat temperatures would also

predict that the thermal response of individuals from Signy would be closer to those from 
Rothera than South Georgia. Although littoral species will experience a much higher range of 
temperatures during low water emersion, habitat temperatures still predict the warmest 
environment at South Georgia. The highest recorded littoral temperature is 12.3°C at Rothera 
(Waller et al., 2006), 10.7°C at Signy (Barnes et al., 1996) and 15.8°C at South Georgia 
(Davenport, 1997). The littoral limpet, Nacella concinna (Strebel 1908), would therefore be 
expected to have a higher thermal capacity than the sub-littoral clam, Laternula elliptica (King 
and Broderip 1831) and higher thermal limits in N. concinna and L. elliptica would be predicted 
from South Georgia, than Signy and Rothera. However, species living at their range limit, where 
they experience temperatures close to their maxima may have a reduced ability to cope with 
further temperature increases (Tomanek, 2005; Deutsch et al., 2008); adaptations that enable 
ectotherms to live in warmer environments may occur at the expense of further acclimatory 
capacity (Stillman, 2003). 
Through sampling these two species from 3 locations within the Southern Ocean, at the 
same time of year, we aim to conduct the first latitudinal comparison of thermal tolerance within 
the Southern Ocean. Environmental history determines thermal response (e.g.. Osovitz and 
Hofmann, 2005) and so all animals were acclimated to the same temperature (0.0°C) and 
maintained under as near identical conditions as possible for 2 months before thermal responses 
were tested. Any differences in thermal response should therefore indicate adaptive differences 
between locations. 
 
2. Materials and Methods 
2.1. Collection and culture 
Limpets, Nacella concinna and the soft shelled clam, Laternula elliptica were collected 
during cruise JR109 on the RRS James Clark Ross and concurrently at Rothera, the British 
Antarctic Survey Research Station at Adeleide Island on Antarctic Peninsula, during early 
summer as detailed in table 1. Except for N. concinna from Signy, which were collected from the 
lowest part of the intertidal, all animals were collected by SCUBA divers. 
After collection all animals were maintained in recirculating aquaria at 0.0±0.3°C, for 63 
days until the start of experiments. Water quality was maintained through biological filtration, 
U.V. sterilisation, protein skimmers and daily water changes. During this period animals were

not fed to reduce any metabolic increment due to feeding (SDA), which can last up to 25 days in 
Antarctic benthic ectotherms (Peck, 1998). Nonetheless, N. concinna were observed grazing on 
biofilms on the tank walls and L. elliptica were seen with siphons open, so both species are likely

At the start of incubation experiments animals were transferred to two 200 litre jacketed 
acrylic tanks (Engineering Design and Plastics, Cambridge, Cambs.) attached to LTD20G 
thermocirculators (Grant instruments Ltd, Shepreth, Cambs.), which maintained temperatures to 
an accuracy of ±0.2°C. The method was similar to that that used by Morley et al. (2007) and 
Peck et al. (2002; 2004; 2007 and 2008). Animals were allowed 48 hours to recover from 
movement stress before temperatures were altered or measurements taken. Temperature was then 
raised at approximately 0.1°C per hour until the required temperatures were reached and then 
animals were allowed 48 hours to recover from any metabolic overshoot (Peck et al., 2002). Due 
to time constraints animals were separated into two groups, which were taken through different 
5.0°C temperature steps, tank 1) 0.0, 5.1 and 10.0°C, tank 2) 2.5, 7.5 and 12.5°C. Following this 
protocol animals were tested over approximately 3 weeks in each tank. 
 
2.2. Oxygen consumption 
Routine metabolic rate was measured in closed cell respirometers, following the 
methodology of Peck (1989), except that oxygen concentration was measured with a Fibox-3 
oxygen meter (Presens GmbH, Regensberg, Germany; e.g. Morley et al., 2007). Oxygen 
sensitive foils were calibrated before each measurement using 5% w/w sodium diothionite for 
0% and fully aerated water for 100%. During trials oxygen concentration was not allowed to fall 
below 70% of air saturation, which is above the threshold for oxy-regulation for L. elliptica 
(Peck et al., 2002). Two empty chambers (controls) were run with each trial to account for 
background oxygen consumption, which was routinely less than 10% of the animal’s 
consumption. The basal metabolic rate of 4-5 individuals was measured for three consecutive 
days after which data were analysed for significant differences in oxygen consumption between 
days. When significant differences were found, daily measurements continued until three stable 
readings were obtained and then temperature was raised. The volume of each animal was 
measured through displacement and subtracted from the volume of water in the respirometer. At 
the end of the experiment dry weight (constant weights at 60°C) and ash free dry weight (dry

At each temperature the circulatory system of L. elliptica was monitored with the 
impedance-based heart rate monitoring system (Buchan et al., 1988). Impedance systems record 
the frequency of heart rate through variations in resistance between two electrodes. Methods 
used were similar to those of Peck et al. (2002). Two 1-mm holes were drilled through the shell 
either side of the heart, and 2mm of tinned 18 standard gauge copper wire electrodes, with the 
coating removed from the tips, were inserted and glued in place with cyanocrylate gel adhesive. 
4 Signy and 4 Rothera L. elliptica had electrodes implanted in each of the two temperature tanks.  
At the end of each temperature step the foot muscle from 4 animals was freeze clamped 
in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80°C for biochemical analysis at the Alfred Wegener Institute in 
Germany (except South Georgia and Signy N. concinna at 10°C for which only 3 animals were 
available). Foot muscle was the chosen tissue as it performs a similar function in both N. 
concinna and L. elliptica. Tissue was ground in a pestle and mortar, under liquid nitrogen, and a 
number of extracts produced for biochemical analysis.  
Temperature steps continued until 50% mortality occurred in the tanks. A further set of 
20 N. concinna and L. elliptica from each location was maintained in the flow through aquarium, 
at ambient temperature, for the duration of the experiment, with no mortalities.   
 
2.3. Biochemical analysis 
Intracellular pH (pHi) and cCO2 could only be measured in tissues of L. elliptica as N. 
concinna foot muscle has large calcium carbonate stores, which would interfere with 
homogenate acidity (Pörtner et al., 1999). Extracts were prepared in a media containing 
160mmol.l-1 potassium fluoride and 1.0 mmol.l-1 nitrilotriacetic acid following the methods of 
Pörtner et al. (1990). pHi was measured in the supernatant of the centrifuged homogenates at 
animal incubation temperature, using needle type fibre optic pH sensors attached to a pH1 micro 
pH meter (Presens GmbH. Regensburg, Germany) whose analogue output signal was boosted 
and digitised through a Powerlab system (AD instruments). Due to the high sensitivity of the 
optode system to solution ionic strength, KCl was added to each calibration buffer to match L. 
elliptica tissue ionic strength of 0.16mol L-1. Due to the small change in tissue pH, calibration 
was conducted using three buffers covering the pH range 6.865 to 7.413 (at 25°C) whose pH

2.4. Analysis 
Conducting the experiment in two tanks simultaneously created a mixed design where, 
within tanks, some individuals were sampled more than once (e.g. for oxygen consumption), but 
different individuals were sampled between tanks. As there was a small, non significant, effect of 
individual (as a random factor in a GLM analysis) a simple analyses was conducted, ignoring 
repeated observations on some individuals (P. Rothery, pers. coms.). ANOVAS with Tukey post-
hoc tests were used to test for differences between locations and temperatures for each species. 
Where ANOVAS indicated only significant differences between locations a separate analysis 
was conducted for each location. Signficant differences was accepted as P<0.05 throughout. 
Oxygen consumption was standardised to that of a 0.373g dry mass N. concinna and a 10.6g dry 
mass L. elliptica (the mean mass of animal used) using scaling coefficients of 0.82 (Fraser et al., 
2002) and 0.73 (Peck et al., 2002) respectively.  
 
3. Results 
3.1. Animal size 
The shell length of L. elliptica sampled for biochemistry was not significantly different 
between locations, table 2. However, due to logistic constraints on collections by SCUBA divers, 
limpets from Rothera were smaller than those from Signy and South Georgia. N. concinna 
collected inter-tidally from Signy were not significantly different in size than N. concinna 
collected sub-tidally from South Georgia.  
 
3.2. L. elliptica 
More than 50% of L. elliptica died during the transition from 5.0 to 10°C and from 7.5 to 
12.5°C so the experiment was stopped at this stage and the upper thermal limit recorded as 
between 7.5 and 10.0°C. Although the sample size was too small to detect significant effects,

Temperature had a significant effect on every biochemical parameter, there were a few 
significant differences between Rothera and Signy L. elliptica (Table 3) and some consistent 
patterns that indicate differences between L. elliptica from the two locations. Although generally 
not significant, at 0.0°C, Rothera L. elliptica had higher oxygen consumption, CS activity and 
higher concentrations of high energy phosphates (PLA, ITP and ATP) than Signy L. elliptica 
suggesting an overall higher metabolism at 0.0°C. Between 0.0 and 2.5ºC there was also a, non-
significant, but consistently greater magnitude change in PLA and ATP (reduction), cCO2 
(increase) and organic acids (increase of succinate and acetate) in Rothera than Signy L. elliptica 
(Fig 1, Table 3).  
The oxygen consumption of L. elliptica rose between 0.0 and 2.5°C for specimens from 
both sites, but no oxygen consumption was significantly different from that at 0.0°C. There was, 
however, a significant drop in oxygen consumption between 2.5 and 7.5°C for both Signy and 
Rothera L. elliptica. Citrate synthase activity at 2.5, 5.1 and 7.5°C was not significantly different 
from that at 0.0°C. However, in a similar fashion to oxygen consumption, L. elliptica from both 
locations had a peak in enzyme activity at 2.5°C, which was significantly higher than activity at 
both 5.1 and 7.5°C.

between L. elliptica from Signy and Rothera. The ATP levels of Rothera L. elliptica were lower 
at both 5.1 and 7.5°C than at 0.0°C, whilst the ATP levels of Signy L. elliptica were only 
reduced at 7.5°C. The ITP concentration of Rothera L. elliptica generally fell upon warming but 
was only significantly lower than 0.0°C at 7.5°C, whilst the ITP concentration of Signy L. 
elliptica was lower at both 0.0°C and 7.5°C than 5.1°C.

3.3. N. concinna 
More than 50% of N. concinna died during the transition from 7.5 to 12.5°C and 10.0 to 
15.0°C so the experiment was stopped at this point. There was no significant effect of location or 
temperature on arginine but there were complex, significant effects on the other adenylates, with 
higher concentrations of both low (AMP and ADP) and high (ATP) energy adenylates at 10.0°C 
(Fig. 2). At 10.0°C AMP was significantly higher in Rothera N. concinna than all treatments 
except Signy N. concinna at 2.5°C and South Georgia at 10.0°C. At 10.0°C ADP was higher in 
N. concinna from all locations. Although there was no significant difference in ATP 
concentration from that at 0.0°C, at 10.0°C the concentration of ATP was higher at all locations 
than at 2.5°C. However, despite this significant increase in ATP for all locations, the increase for 
South Georgia N. concinna appeared to be less (Fig. 2). The PLA concentration of South Georgia 
N. concinna was also lower at 10.0°C than at either 0.0 or 5.1°C.

acetate and proprionate were only significantly elevated in South Georgia N. concinna at 10.0°C 
(Fig.3). The large inter-individual variation in organic acids at 10°C is typical of biochemical 
responses around physiological limits as some individuals reach their limits before others. For N. 
concinna from all locations, citrate synthase activity determined in tissue samples collected at 
each temperature generally increased upon warming but was only significantly higher at 7.5 and 
10.0°C (Fig.4).

4. Discussion 
Measuring a suite of physiological and biochemical parameters gave a comprehensive 
picture of how tissue energy status changed in response to a 5.0°C per week temperature 
elevation. It also allowed comparisons of the responses of L. elliptica, and N. concinna, collected 
from different geographic locations. As all animals were collected at the same time, were held 
under nearly identical conditions for approximately 2 months before thermal sensitivity was 
tested and they were tested over a maximum of 3 weeks, any consistent differences between 
locations are most likely due differences in response between animals from these locations.  
 
4.1. L. elliptica 
The critical limit, which was confirmed by a drop in oxygen consumption, a drop in 
energy status of the adenylates, an increase in anaerobic end products of metabolism (the organic 
acids) and a drop in intracellular pH, occurred between 5.1 and 7.5°C, which is comparable to 
that measured previously, over a similar rate of temperature change (6°C; Peck et al., 2002). 
Anaerobic metabolism is generally considered one of the protective mechanisms that allow time-
limited survival above critical temperatures (Pörtner, 2006). However, molluscs in particular can 
have high anaerobic capacities that can be utilised to survive hypoxia for days or weeks, 
particularly when accompanied by metabolic depression (e.g. Holmes and Miller, 2006; Morley 
et al., 2007; Long et al., 2008). Reductions in citrate synthase activity and metabolic rate suggest 
that thermal limitation may have started at a lower temperature, with pejus limits below 5.1°C. 
Succinate and volatile fatty acid formation set in somewhat earlier in Rothera than the Signy L. 
elliptica. This would indicate that, as a consequence of severe oxygen limitation, the critical 
temperature is lower in the Rothera than the Signy population. The greater, but non-significant, 
biochemical changes between 0.0 and 2.5 ºC for Rothera L. elliptica, coupled with significant 
accumulation of carbon dioxide in the haemolymph, which shows that Rothera L. elliptica have a 
lower capacity for gas exchange at 5.0 ºC (cf Peck et al., 2002), also suggest that pejus limits are 
lower in Rothera than Signy L. elliptica. After 2 months at 0.0 ºC, there were also signs of

The lethal limit in the current study also occurred at a similar temperature, between 7.5 
and 10.0°C (within 15 days), to that recorded previously (9°C within 25 days; Peck et al., 2002). 
The similarity of lethal limits between Rothera and Signy L. elliptica, is consistent with the 
hypothesis that thermal capacities will be matched to the experienced environment (both -2 to 
+1°C), although the lower pejus limits of Rothera L. elliptica compared to Signy indicate subtle 
differences in thermal tolerance between locations. Clearly, studies incorporating L. elliptica 
from South Georgia, which is at the northern limit of its range, are needed to quantify how close 
it is living to its upper thermal limits and therefore with reduced capacity to cope with further 
temperature increases (Stillman, 2003).  Such studies are crucial to our understanding of species 
wide thermal capacity and therefore the ability of species to cope with environmental change. 
Acclimations of L. elliptica at 3-4°C would indicate if South Georgia L. elliptica have 
adaptations to cope with higher maximum experienced summer temperature.  
 
4.2. N. concinna 
Due to the constraints on geographical sampling within the Southern Ocean, there were 
sampling differences between N. concinna collected at different locations. N. concinna were 
collected from the bottom of the inter-tidal from Signy, compared to sub-tidal animals collected 
from South Georgia and Rothera, however, all N. concinna were collected from depths shallower 
than 6m. A recent study found small, non-consistent, genetic differences between inter-tidal and 
15m N. concinna from Potter Cove, King George Island, but not between inter-tidal and 6m N. 
concinna (de Aranzamendi et al., 2008). Different biochemical responses to emersion were also 
evident between 15m and intertidal N. concinna, also from King George Island (Weihe and 
Abele, In Press) was also evident This suggests that comparisons of 6m (Rothera), 2-3m (South 
Georgia) and inter-tidal (Signy) N. concinna will not be affected by population differences 
between animals collected from different depths. N. concinna collected in the middle of summer 
and tested within days of collection had no significant (t=0.57, p=0.57) differences in upper 
lethal thermal limits (1°C  per day) between those collected in the inter-tidal (11.6°C) or sub-
tidal (6m, 10.8°C; SAM, unpublished data). The lack of any clear differences between Rothera 
 12
sub-tidal and Signy inter-tidal N. concinna, in the present study suggests that they respond 
similarly to temperature, after a 2 month acclimation to 0.0°C.

Rothera N. concinna were also smaller than those from the other two locations, which 
could introduce complicating factors due to growth and age differences as well as wider thermal 
windows of small specimens (e.g. Pörtner 2002; Peck et al., 2007; Gsottbauer et al., 2007). 
However, broad scale metabolic differences (see below), in the response to temperature, were 
found between South Georgia and both Signy and Rothera N. concinna, which are unlikely to be 
caused by size differences. Accepting these caveats, the present geographic comparisons within 
the Southern Ocean, show for the first time specific responses of the adenylates, organic acids 
and oxygen consumption to temperature, which suggest differences in critical limits and the 
metabolic mechanisms employed to cope with acute temperatures close to these limits. There 
was little evidence to suggest that Rothera or Signy N. concinna were temperature limited over 
the range 0.0 to 10.0°C with measures of aerobic metabolism (oxygen consumption, citrate 
synthase activity and ATP concentration) all increasing with temperature above 2.5°C. This 
contrasts strongly with the pattern in L. elliptica which didn’t show a reduction in these metrics 
at temperatures above 2.5°C. This inicates they were suffering heat stress and have a narrower 
thermal window than N. concinna.  
In South Georgia N. concinna, citrate synthase activity and therefore the capacity of 
aerobic metabolism in the mitochondria, increased with temperature in a similar fashion to 
limpets from the other locations. However, in contrast to Rothera and Signy N. concinna, two 
indicators of metabolism decreased in South Georgia N. concinna at higher temperatures. 
Oxygen consumption peaked somewhere between 2.5 and 5.3°C and then declined whilst the 
PLA pool, for buffering rapid ATP production, also declined above 5.1°C. Both of these suggest 
a lower critical limit between 5.1 and 10.0°C (but perhaps as low as 2.5°C) for South Georgia N. 
concinna, which was supported by the sharp increase in organic acids between 7.5 and 10.0°C 
and therefore the recruitment of anaerobic pathways.  
The wider thermal tolerance of N. concinna compared to L. elliptica is not surprising 
considering it ranges into the intertidal and can therefore be exposed to a more variable thermal 
environment. However, the difference in maximum littoral temperatures recorded so far, 12.3°C 
at Rothera (Waller et al., 2006) 10.7°C at Signy (Barnes et al., submitted) and 15.8°C at South 
Georgia (Davenport, 1997) was not reflected in any difference in the upper lethal limits for N. 
 13
concinna from different locations after 2 months acclimation to 0.0°C (10.0 to 12.5°C). 
Davenport reported a short term survival limit of 15.6°C (12 hour exposure) for N. concinna at 
South Georgia, higher than our medium term, 22 day, temperature limit of between 10.0 and 
12.5°C. This is not unexpected as different thermal limits and protective mechanisms might be 
expected if different rates of heating or cooling are used (Terblanche et al., 2007; Barnes et al., 
2008; Peck et al., in press). This difference may also have been because N. concinna tested by 
Davenport were acclimatised to summer conditions which could have raised their lethal limit 
above that of animals acclimated to 0.0°C. However, it should also be noted that due to 
behavioural adaptations, such as utilisation of cryptic habitats and evaporative cooling (Branch, 
1981), body temperatures of limpets in the field are unlikely to reach these temperatures. The 
maximum foot temperature of a Rothera N. concinna exposed on a sunny day has been shown to 
be 8.8°C, although the average was much lower, 3.3 to 3.8°C, ranging from 1.5 to 9.1°C below 
air temperature (Clark et al., 2008). If this relationship holds for South Georgia N. concinna then 
foot temperature is unlikely to exceed their short-term (daily exposure) lethal limit during low 
water emersion but might approach their medium term (weekly exposure) limit. Although N. 
concinna are regularly exposed in the intertidal zone at Rothera and Signy, at South Georgia, it is 
mainly a sub-tidal species (Davenport, 1997) and only rarely found above mean low water spring 
tide level, reducing the risk of exposure to damaging high temperatures. The few inter-tidal 
individuals found at South Georgia inhabit sheltered microhabitats and not exposed surfaces, 
which are colonised by a siphonariid limpet, Kerguelenella lateralis. At its northern geographic 
limit differences in habitat utilisation may be key to reducing the likelihood of N. concinna being 
exposed to air temperatures close to its upper limit. They may therefore have evolved a high 
anaerobic capacity to allow short-term, passive, survival during less frequent exposure (Pörtner, 
2002). This fits with a growing body of evidence which shows that adaptation to life at range 
limits may actually make animals less able to cope with further temperature increases (Stillman, 
2003, Tomanek, 2005, Deutsch et al., 2008).

is unlikely to be effective over longer time scales (Pörtner, 2006). After initial shock, animals

acclimatory mechanisms with associated changes in tissue biochemistry and structure. The 
greater thermal flexibility of N. concinna than L. elliptica was further evidenced by the increase

Two month long incubations of N. concinna from South Georgia, Signy and Rothera, 
long enough for seasonal acclimation, led to a reduction in the surface area of mitochondrial 
cristae per unit muscle fibre volume (Morley et al., submitted). Latitudinal comparisons showed 
that acclimated N. concinna from South Georgia had a higher citrate synthase activity than 
Rothera N. concinna, which was negatively correlated with mitochondrial density across 
locations. This strongly suggested an adaptation for fewer, more efficient mitochondria in 
acclimated N. concinna from the northern limit of their range (Morley et al., submitted). Tissue 
samples of N. concinna acclimated to 3.0°C are currently being analysed to investigate if 
changes in aerobic pathways were accompanied by a change of anaerobic scope. These 
differences in the mechanisms underlying, and the limits of, thermal tolerance between N. 
concinna from South Georgia and both Signy and Rothera N. concinna are supported by genetic 
differences, which suggest South Georgia N. concinna are a separate population (Beaumont and 
Wei, 1991).  
The Scotia arc region of the Southern Ocean has one of the fastest warming climates on 
the planet (Meredith and King, 2005). If this rate of warming is faster than the rate of 
evolutionary adaptation, then the acclimatory ability of individuals, populations and species is 
likely to be a key determinate of their survival (e.g. Peck, 2008). Species with wider geographic 
ranges are thought to be more resistant to extinction (Jablonski, 1986), which may in part be due 
to the wider range of environments they experience. This should in turn lead to wider genetic 
variation and therefore an increased physiological capacity to cope with environmental 
perturbations (the climate variability hypothesis; Stevens, 1989). The current study has found 
differences in thermal response of marine ectotherms between locations on the Scotia Arc and 
Antarctic Peninsula. Investigations of a wider range of species will confirm if these differences 
are an adaptive response to differences in experienced environment. Latitudinal comparisons 
testing for differences in capacity between animals from different locations within the Southern 
Ocean could be a key tool for predicting the vulnerability of species to the current trend of 
warming.
